How can I expand the output display to see more columns of a Pandas DataFrame? When I use the describe() function on a DataFrame with more than five columns, the statistics are suppressed and something similar to the following is returned:

```
>> Index: 8 entries, count to max
>> Data columns:
>> x1          8  non-null values
>> x2          8  non-null values
>> x3          8  non-null values
>> x4          8  non-null values
>> x5          8  non-null values
>> x6          8  non-null values
>> x7          8  non-null values
```
The "8" value is given whether there are 6 or 7 columns. What does the "8" refer to? Is there a way to widen the display of output in either interactive or script-execution mode? I have already tried dragging the IDLE window larger, as well as increasing the "Configure IDLE" width options, but these did not solve my problem.

The issue you're encountering with the Pandas `describe()` function is likely due to the default display settings in Pandas, which are designed to limit the amount of data printed to the console to make it more manageable. The number "8" you're seeing refers to the number of entries in the index range, which are the different statistics calculated by `describe()` (e.g., count, mean, std, min, 25%, 50%, 75%, max).

To expand the output display in Pandas to see more columns, you can adjust the display options using the `pandas.set_option()` function. Here's how you can do it:

```python
import pandas as pd

# Set the display option to show more columns
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', None)

# If you want to see more rows, you can also set this
pd.set_option('display.max_rows', None)

# Now when you use the describe() function, it should show all columns
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'x1': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8],
    'x2': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9],
    'x3': [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10],
    'x4': [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11],
    'x5': [5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12],
    'x6': [6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13],
    'x7': [7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14]
})

# Use describe to see the statistics
print(df.describe())
```

This code sets the option to display all columns (`None` means no limit) and, if needed, all rows. These settings should allow you to see the full output of `describe()` with all statistics for each column in your DataFrame.

If you're using an interactive environment like Jupyter Notebook, these settings will apply to all cells once set. In script mode, you'll need to set them for each session or include them in your script.

Additionally, if you're using an environment like IDLE, you might want to consider using a different environment such as Jupyter Notebook, which provides a more flexible and interactive display for working with Pandas DataFrames.
